STATE TREASURER REPORT OF STATE TREASURER July 1, 1928 to June 30, 1930 STATE OF NEBRASKA TREASURY DEPARTMENT State Capitol, Lincoln, Nebraska July 1, 1930 To His Excellency, Arthur J. Weaver, Governor of the State of Nebraska, . I Lincoln, Nebraska Dear Sir:- In compliance with the law, I have the honor to transmit herewith my report of the transactions of the Treasury Department of the State of Nebraska from July 1, 1928 to June 30, 1930. During the biennium, this Department has received from all sources $49,979,802.49, and the total disbursements were $46,926,223.31, leaving a cash balance on hand June 30, 1930 of $7,532,903.22, as shown by the following report. CURRENT REVENUE FUNDS In this group, you will note these funds are our most active accounts — the largest being the General Fund and the Gasoline Tax Fund. The General Fund is derived principally by taxation, although quite a sum is derived from corporation, car line and insurance premium taxes. See Schedule A-l. The Gasoline Tax, (4<? per gallon of gasoline imported into the state) brings into the treasury approximately nine million dollars per annum. See Statement of Receipts and Disbursements for the year July 1, 1929 to June 30, 1930. It will be- remembered that during the period July 1, 1928 and April 1, 1929, the tax was still 2<f per gallon, — therefore the receipts for the year July 1, 1928 to June 30, 1929 are made up of both the 2t and 4<? tax, not making nearly as good a showing as for the following year. CURRENT TRUST FUNDS These funds are derived principally from- our trust funds invested m bonds, and school land rentals. Nebraska has $10,737,379.43 invested m bonds for our Permanent School Fund, the income from which together with school- land rentals, insurance licenses, etc. (See Schedule B-l) brings m an annual income of approximately $1,000,000.00. This is credited to the Temporary School Fund and is apportioned among all the school districts m the state. The income on the $1,946,069.34 invested m bonds for the Soldiers' Relief Fund, is credited to the Soldiers' Relief Incoma Fund, which is spent as state aid for ex-soldiers and their families who are m need. In like manner, trust funds invested for the University Endowment, :Agricul_ture College Endowment and Normal School Endow - ment Funds, bring m an income, which with rentals from school lands belonging to these funds, is credited to the University Income and Normal School Income Funds.

REPORT OF PERMANENT TRUST FUNDS Under this classification, we have the funds which are invested and re-invested m bonds, the income from which becomes "Current Trust Funds" as stated in' the previous paragraph. For the biennium, bonds were redeemed m the amount of $3,385,791.89, and $3,739,173.15 were purchased. STATE TREASURY DEPARTMENT BANK DEPOSITS During 1 the biennium, the State received the sum of $202,425.10 as earned upon daily balances from deposits of state funds. Since the year 1900, Nebraska has had no bonded indebtedness. We are strictly on a cash basis. Our monthly statements will show that there has not been a single account overdrawn during the entire biennium. Our state has adopted the policy of raising the money before we spend it, and if this policy is continued there is no danger of the state being short of funds at any time to meet all its obligations. Respectfully submitted, W. M. STEBBINS, State Treasurer.
